statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: College of Charleston 77, Georgia Southern 66
article.story: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. -- Bobby Cremins moved a step closer to the NCAA tournament as Dontaye Draper had 23 points to lead the College of Charleston to a 77-66 victory over Georgia Southern in the Southern Conference tournament quarterfinals Thursday night. The third-seeded Cougars (21-10) next face Appalachian State, the tournament's No. 2 seed, in the semifinals on Friday. That winner would play for the SoCon title -- and the league's automatic NCAA bid -- on Saturday. Cremins, in his first year back after six years out of coaching, hasn't reached the NCAAs since 1996 with the last of his 10 Georgia Tech teams to make it. And it appeared Cremins' hopes of getting there this year would fade as well after Georgia Southern (15-16) used a 10-5 run to take a 35-28 halftime lead. But the Cougars, who shot just 33 percent in the opening period, found their game after the break. They opened the half with a 27-12 run to take control and break a three-game tournament losing streak. The Eagles closed to 66-59 in the final three minutes. But David Lawrence had a three-point play and Draper a bucket to restore the lead. As the final minutes ticked down, Cremins clapped and pumped his fist at his players, urging them to stay focused to the end. When Jermaine Johnson broke free for a slam with 1:34 left to make it 75-59, Cremins looked up at the scoreboard with arms raised in triumph. It had been a long time coming for the Cougars, who went 19-0 in their debut SoCon season of 1999 but had fallen short ever since. Josh Jackson had 16 points, 12 of them in the second half, while Johnson added 15 points for Charleston. The two were a a combined 16 of 19 from the field. The Eagles finish with their first losing season since 1998-99 and their first under coach Jeff Price. Louis Graham led Georgia Southern with 17 points.
